author: lnolan143

description.text: Just what thingiverse needs, another box... I see that fdavies created http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:635 a box with hinged lid 3 years ago. I drew this one in OpenScad and it's parametric so you can scale it to the size you prefer. I was going to use minkowski() to do the rounding on the top of the box, but my machine doesn't have the power to render it that way, so there's some code in there that isn't used and a lot of the files are ones I used while I was working and then discarded. I haven't printed this yet, but I'm hoping to soon.

To build it you will need: hinge.scad
box_main.scad
box.scad
lid.scad Edit box_main to set length, width, depth Make your stl files with box.scad and lid.scad print...

author: Thought_Builder

description.text:
This is Taylor's Theorem approximation created in Mathematica version 10. George Mason University Math 493 for Mathematics Through 3D Printing.

This project demonstrates Taylor’s theorem giving an approximation to the cosine function. The Taylor series is given by f(x)= ∑_(n=0) to ∞ cn (x-a)^n, where cn = f^n(a)/n!.
where f(x)=cos(x) and a=pi.
Using polynomials functionality to compute the nth degree, the nth degree is increased by even numbers which brings us to a better approximation.
Let x^n/n! , where n equals a positive even integer starting at n=0
cos⁡(x)=1-x^2/2!+x^4/4!-x^6/6!+x^8/8!-x^10/10!…
Note: For x^n/n! , where n equals a positive odd integer starting at n=1 will create an approximation to the sine function.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Raft not required.
Thickness of design was originally 0.1, but when taking off supports damaged the design. Thickness was increased to 0.5, which made it easier to remove support.

Instructions

In Mathematica the following function were created and then put together towards the end in output5.

f[x,y]:={x,y,Cos[x]};
Output1 = ParametricPlot3D[f[x,y],{x,-8,8}, {y,2,7} PlotStyle->{Green,Thickness[0.5]}, Mesh->False]

h[x,y]:={x,y,(1-x^2/2!)};
Output2 = ParametricPlot3D[h[x,y],{x,-4,4}, {y,2,7} PlotStyle->{Red,Thickness[0.5]}, Mesh->False]

g[x,y]:={x,y,(1-x^2/2!+x^4/4!)};
Output3 = ParametricPlot3D[g[x,y],{x,-4,4}, {y,2,7} PlotStyle->{Blue,Thickness[0.5]}, Mesh->False]

k[x,y]:={x,y,(1-x^2/2!+x^4/4!-x^6/6!+x^8/8!-x^10/10!)};
Output4 = ParametricPlot3D[k[x,y],{x,-6,6}, {y,2,7} PlotStyle->{Yellow,Thickness[0.5]}, Mesh->False]

output5=Show[{output1, output2, output3, output4}]

print_settings.Notes:: I printed my front and back halves without any infill, just 2 perimeters to save filament. These two parts will require support because they are half-circle arches. Nothing else should need any support though.
print_settings.Infill:: 20% or whatever works best for you

description.text:
EDIT April 25, 2016: Another scaling mistake! Thanks to Zarni for noticing that the Outer and Inner Gun Sections were also at the incorrect scale. I had borrowed those from BrandonW6's model, but his drone is 25% bigger than mine and I never saved them at the correct scale. The files have been replaced with the right sizes. Let's hope this is the last mistake!

EDIT April 15, 2016: Special thanks to NoLiver92 for noticing that the part "My Linkage v4_fixed.STL" was not scaled properly. I have removed this part and replaced it with "Linkage v4.STL" which should be at the same scale as the rest of the model. (Also updated instructions to reflect this filename change.) Sorry for the mistake!

If you enjoy the movie "Oblivon" with Tom Cruise and Morgan Freeman, you also might want your very own "evil R2-D2 / Portal Sentry" Drone model!

This is my take on a replica of the awesome drones from the film (sorry, it doesn't come with sound effects!)

Special thanks to BrandonW6 for allowing me to reuse his model for the guns (if it ain't broke don't fix it, right?) and for inspiring me to attempt my most challenging CAD modeling project to date.

Parts you'll need (see the 3rd image for all printed parts):
1x Drone Front Half_fixed.STL
1x Drone Back Half_fixed.STL
1x Engine-Main.STL
2x Engine-Secondary.STL
1x Engine-Tertiary.STL
1x Engine-Quaternary.STL
1x Faceplate.STL
2x Inner_Gun_Section_fixed.STL
2x Outer_Gun_Section_fixed.STL
2X Linkage Mount.STL
2X Linkage v4.STL

Optional:
1x Stand.STL

Note: Please excuse the triangular wedges on "Linkage v4". They are too thin to slice and print and are just an artifact of the "loft feature" I used when making the model. You can see in the actual parts that this wedge does not print out.

The front and back half pieces have holes for a bit of spare filament to use for alignment and to better hold the glue. I simply used White Elmer's Glue-All (PVA glue) to hold the parts together. You could also use cyanoacrylate (super glue).

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 microns looks great!

Infill:

20% or whatever works best for you

Notes:

I printed my front and back halves without any infill, just 2 perimeters to save filament. These two parts will require support because they are half-circle arches. Nothing else should need any support though.

More info:

I didn't have any white filament, so I wound up priming this with a can of spray primer then using an airbrush to paint it white, hence why it's so smooth looking (PLA print). If you can print white ABS and acetone vapor smooth it you might wind up with a very shiny smooth drone!

comments.author: hukuzatuna

comments.text: I haven't seen anyone do it, but it shouldn't be hard! If you look at the Thingiview for the front and back halves of the body, you'll see that the model is already hollow. You're essentially left with an empty cylinder that's about 37mm tall and has a 44mm diameter. As far as snap-fit goes, this is already designed so that the two halves are held together using pegs. If you find just the right size (think along the lines of bamboo skewers, chopsticks, lollipop sticks, etc.) you should be able to securely friction fit the front and back halves of the body without gluing them together. Sounds like a fun project, good luck!

comments.text: SonOfAGun!!! I knew something didn't look right in those photos but I didn't look closely. This is what I get for printing my model in January but waiting to post to thingiverse until April, I forgot which parts needed to be rescaled. I borrowed the inner and outer gun sections from BrandonW6, but his drone model was based on a 100 mm sphere, whereas mine is based on an 80 mm sphere. So yes, the guns are supposed to be 20% smaller than what I posted, I didn't realize I hadn't saved them at the proper scale. I will post the correct sized STL's, good catch

comments.author: NoLiver92

comments.text: The linkage mount fits on the body of the drone. Looking at the 3rd and 4th pictures, the linkage mount is black, the linkage is gray. just glue the linkage to the mount. It may be easier to glue the linkage to the outer gun section first so that you can align those circles more easily. Then you can glue the mount to the linkage, and finally glue that whole assembly to the drone.

title: Sweet stackable XT60 panel and plug mounts
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I needed some plugs for a panel box and rather than bulky plugs, I used XT60 connectors from my R/C toys.

You can place the XT60 male or female end as needed. I made flat panel mounts and plug housings that can stack as well. This makes a solid-feeling plug setup.

You will need:
Plug mount- 2 M3x10mm bolts (I used socket heads. It's what I had.) and 2 M3 locknuts
Panel mount holder- 2 M3x10mm bolts and 2 M3 locknuts to hold the XT60
Panel mount backing- 2 M3x10mm + your bulkhead thickness (ex. 10mm+3mm bulkhead =~15mm bolt) bolts and 2 M3 locknuts

If you are stacking them, allow 10mm for each housing; 3 stacked fittings= 30mm bolt

There are two plug mount files. One has arrows pointing in and one has arrows pointing out. This can be a reminder of POWER IN or SIGNAL OUT, etc.

Have fun!

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20mm layers minimum

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

2 perimeters, printed in PLA. This is going to be a close fit, so your machine should be in good tune. My XT60s fit in with no modification and stay locked in when closed.

Prints great at .20mm and no cleanup other than maybe a light chamfer pass around the locknut holding areas with an x-acto to make it easy to insert them.

You should not be tightening these bolts to crushing torque, just snug, OK?

description.text: Replacement hubcap for my Honda CRV

Designed to print using aquasolve support for the indent and Honda logo on the front (underside of print).
Use silver filament for the print.
Keep an eye on the print while doing the support, The Honda logo is 0.6mm deep, so once the support has printed to 0.4mm, then change the filiment to black, so the logo comes out black on the silver background, but still recessed as per the original hubcaps

Note: The shape is not quite right, I will have to improve my knowledge working 3d software, and update this some time. - but it still looks very similar to the original, and fits.

author: vladimirpers

description.text:
Here's a quick remix of mwu's RJ45 receiver to make multiple receivers in one block. For my purposes, I plan to screw the whole unit to a wooden base (joist, etc) so there are screw holes in between the modules for a wood or drywall screw.

In order to customize, edit the open scad file and change the call to 'multi_reciever'

multi_receiver(receiver_spacing,number_of_modules,hole_dia)

  • receiver_spacing is width of the reciever plus the solid material in between
  • number_of_modules is the number of receivers
  • hole_dia is the diameter of the screw mounting hole

Included is a model with 4 receivers, 25mm spacing, 5mm diameter screw holes.

I remixed this from the Rubik's Companion Cube. I noticed that you didnt have to use the core file and just use the core from another real Rubik's Cube. I managed to fit it together and it works pretty well. But then I realized that I could just print the surface bits and have them act like 3D stickers.

Print 6 of these "Sticker Templates" in any color you like to make a 6 color Companion Rubik's Cube without having to paint it. Not sure the best adhesive to use yet, Ill experiment and update later.

Haven't really tested it yet so any feedback is welcome.

description.text:
This is an absolutely useless object for everyone but me. It holds a planetary gear.
ratio 1 :4 and is posted for backup purposes. The material is PLA except for the ABS cable clip thingy.

The middle black sprocket drives the cable, and the end sprocket is fixed to the other cable, therefore the motor is also fixed. This low budget fix really could need a 12V motor or a highly expensive stepperdriver and steppermotor.

The IR gate / rotary encoder disk, has 36 pulses for one rotation. It is fixed to the first gear by small screws. To remove these parts, first unscrew the IR gate from the unit.

P.S. Don't blame me if you now realize you could have made yourself a cup of coffee, instead of reading this...

:-/

comments.text: Why do you prefer PLA in this situation? ABS is stronger, and more importantly lighter. (ABS has a density of 1.05 g/cm^3 vs PLA at 1.25 g/cm^3) Every bit of weight you can cut out gives a better thrust to weight ratio, making the copter more responsive, and increasing flight times.

title: 12VDC or 24VDC universal laptop power supply w/ anderson powerpole connectors

description.text:
By changing parts this can be built as either a 12V or a 24V to laptop power supply. Most people will probably find the 12V version more useful since that will work in a normal vehicle.

This is a modification of my previous "DIY 24VDC laptop power supply" project and uses the same parts but has a few modifications:

  • Instead of a power cord coming out of it, this has a place to mount anderson powerpole connectors. These are used a lot by ham radio operators, but you can absolutely make an adapter to go to a standard cig lighter adapter.
  • The barrel no longer protrudes from the box.

Parts list:

For the 24VDC version:

  • http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00C4QVTNU - DC buck step-down DC voltage converter

For the 12VDC version:

  • http://smile.amazon.com/Yeeco-Converter-Adjustable-Regulation-Stabilizer/dp/B00RXJJGE2 - DC boost step-up DC voltage converter

For both versions:

  • http://www.ebay.com/itm/10-pcs-DC-Power-Female-Jack-2-1-x-5-5-mm-Barrel-Plug-Connector-Adapter-Terminal-/381177777840 - you only need one of these, but I can't find them in packs of only 1
  • http://www.ebay.com/itm/2-Pr-Philmore-15A-DC-Power-Connectors-20-16-AWG-Wire-Sermos-Anderson-Powerpole-/281867449190?hash=item41a09bf366:g:dSkAAOSwcBhWVie2 - Anderson powerpole connectors

Build instructions

I used 16AWG wires for everything -- you'll never exceed 15 amps, so that should be safe.

  1. Cut one pair of wires about 4" long and strip about 1cm from each end of both wires. Use a small screwdriver to connect those wires between the output of the board with the matching (+ to +, - to -) terminals on the barrel connector.

  2. Cut another pair of wires about 8" long and strip one end of each. Attach them to the input terminals on the board. Fold the wires under the board and then mount the board in the case so that the output is towards the larger open part of the case. The barrel connector and the wires going under the board should both come out on that side.

  3. Mount the barrel by carefully inserting the tapered socket into the hole on the side of the case with the screw terminals up; pressing towards the bottom of the case should then snap it in between the wall and the small protrusion on the bottom of the case and hold it in place. Make sure as you do this that the input wires stay free.

  4. Install the powerpole connectors on the input and then mount them in the matching opening. The knob sticking up in the middle of the platform should insert cleanly into the hole between the red and black connector and hold it in place; if it doesn't, carefully trim it a bit with a razor knife to fix it.

  5. Connect the appropriate (12VDC or 24VDC, depending on which board you have) power to the powerpoles (ask in comments for suggestions on how to get it there if you aren't familiar with them). Using a voltmeter, place one probe on each of the screws in the output terminal to measure the voltage. Use a small screwdriver to set the voltage to the desired output; MacBook Pro laptops can handle anywhere from 16-20V, and most laptops are okay with 19V, but you may want to do a bit of research on your laptop to be sure. We're not responsible if you blow something up!

  6. Once you've set the voltage, install the lid and screw it down. Make sure that the knob above the powerpole connectors go in correctly to help hold them in place.

  7. Connect 12vdc to the powerpoles and plug your laptop adapter cable (you can find them with just about any battery system which recharges laptops; if anyone has good links, send them to us in the comments). Here are the ones we know of:
  • Apple Magsafe 1: http://smile.amazon.com/HIOTECH-MagSafe-Adapter-Connector-MacBook/dp/B016ODO8DG
  • Apple Magsafe 2: http://smile.amazon.com/i-smile%C2%AE-Connector-MagSafe-Macbook-5-5x2-5mm/dp/B00OL9QO6U

description.text:
Hello

This is a bigger body for the Kame.
I am still working on it, but it should be okay as a starting point for others.

Intend

It allows to integrate a 800mAh 2s Lipo, a strong 6A BEC, a pin header or small prototype board and a ultrasonic sensor. There is a hole in the back to to install an on/off switch and a battery chute for easy battery access.

Customization

The servo holes fit my generic cheap 12g metal gear servos, but you can set the parameters in the OpenSCAD-file to make them fit your needs. However, try to use tough servos, they are under direct load all the time in this design.

Software

Modified software is in development, trying to make use of the ultrasonic sensor. The sourcecode can be found in the GitHub repository which is a fork of the miniKame repository: https://github.com/Blomdoft/fatKame

So the idea is to have this really non-compliant little web server for issuing commands to the bot. Works fine so far.

About Controller Boards

I am using a NodeMCU Amica Development Board, which basically is a ESP8266-12 with a full pinout board underneath it, there are many like these and they are inexpensive.

Struggles to use the sensor

The ESP8266 boards have the problem that they only offer 8 "real" GPIO pins, so using the ultrasonsic sensor with them is quite tedious. An additional GPIO can be used for sending out data if no interrupt is required (triggering of the ultrasonic sensor works fine). But receiving back the echo requires freeing up GPIO9 or GPIO10, and that means making modifications to the way that the flash chip on the board is wired. Think soldering SMD. Still looking for a better solution to this.

Servo mapping

board_pins[0] = D1; // front left inner
board_pins[1] = D4, // front right inner
board_pins[2] = D8; // front left outer
board_pins[3] = D6; // front right outer
board_pins[4] = D7; // back left inner
board_pins[5] = D5; // back right inner
board_pins[6] = D2; // back left outer
board_pins[7] = D3; // back right outer

Thank you!

BIG thanks to bqLabs, this is a supernice bot!

RepRap

Prusa i3

No

Yes

15%

The upper part is a bit ugly to print, I am printing it in natural direction with a lot of support. As the bad surface finish then is on the inside, it does not matter that much.
I took the FreeCAD file from the Kame, failed to modify it and made a new one in OpenSCAD. My OpenSCAD skills are still bad, so the file is definitly not nice.

comments.text: Works really well and very solid design,  took about 12 hours to print. The lugs that connect it to the body could do with being extended by an extra 1mm as I had to put a lot of pressure on to get it to snap in and broke one of the smaller ones off in the process, or a little sanding may do the job,  but other than that brilliant for 1kg spools.  Thanks
comments.author: Newarth

comments.text:
Thanks again PrintingPetzi. Sorry for the delay I have been out of the office. We have uploaded another version as per your recommendations. The spool has been pushed back as far as it can go with this design and we have reduced the spool retention distance back to 70mm. I hope this works for you.
You can find version 3 here http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1690199
comments.author: Redstack

comments.text: This is a great spool holder. It fits perfect on the back of an ultimaker 2+. Maybe if the spool would sit closer to the back, the filament will roll of nicer from the spool. I had a spool jammed twice. Maybe you can do a 2nd version of it...? Anyway, thanks for the wonderful work.
comments.author: PrintingPetzi

comments.text:
Thank you very much for the feedback PintingPetzi.
We have revised the design and posted a new version that moves the spool 6mm back towards the printer. This also gives additional spool clearance (now 76mm long). I hope this fixes your issue.
comments.author: PrintingPetzi

comments.text:
O.K. I printed an tested the spool holder. It works a little better, but since the spool can now slide sideways on the holder, it has to be a spool without bars for center to the outside. Otherwise the problem gets worse. I would recommend keep the width of 70 mm and move the whole reel towards the backplate all the way. So the distance between the backplate and the spool is only the 5-6 mm. (The reel-guards left side (left gets attached to the back) should touch the backplate). That should work the best because the filament won't get feeded in an angle.) Maybe if you have time do alter the design, I can print and test it.
Thank you.
comments.author: Redstack

comments.text: Wow! Thank you very much for your fast response and the additional work. I will download and test the spool holder and give you a feedback on the new design.
comments.author: Redstack

description.text:
This is to connect a 4 inch dryer vent exhaust hose to an 80mm PC case fan.

I run my printer in my basement and have cats who like to hang out with me while I'm working. I will occasionally want to print in ABS and other materials that are unpleasant to smell and may not be great for your health to breath (particularly for small pets).

I needed to create an exhaust system that would pull the smell/fumes out of the living area and duct it outside. I use an acrylic enclosure on my Robo 3D R1 Plus that I purchased from PrintedSolid.com. I went to my local PC and hardware stores and picked up all the supplies I needed...except for a reliable method of connecting the vent hose to the case fan....

So...this is my solution. There is a similar solution out there for use with 3 inch dryer hose, but the 3 inch wasn't available locally to me, so I went with the 4 inch.

The square section simply slides over the entire outside of the case fan. There are NO fasteners required!

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

low

comments.text: How do you keep it from melting?  i.e. what kind of insulator between the mount and the grill?
comments.author: datasmasher

comments.text: checkout the photo with the metal plate. It is mild steal. It blocks most of the heat then I have a layer of lid gasket material. With those 2 layers the highest temp I have measured was 90c (pit was 500f) a good 30c below the melting point of ABS. This servo has been in service for hundreds of hours. I wouldn't use copper as it transfers 200 times the heat of mild steal or stainless.

title: Customizable Button
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple utility for creating your very own buttons!

The idea for this thing came from the sudden disheartening realization that nobody ever seems to have the button they need. Sure, everybody has a whirlwind of spare buttons laying around, but we can never seem to find the right ones when we need them.

Enter: The Button Maker. With this customizer, you can fine-tune your basic button, adjusting its thickness, diameter, how thick and how tall its trim is (if you want it to have a trim at all!), how many holes it should have, and more! Best of all, the customizer handles all the fancy trigonometry for you, so you know your button will be layed out perfectly!

Have fun, and get makin' loads of buttons for your family, friends, relatives, neighbours, mailmen, passerby...

Rounding Your Buttons

In the future, I will be adding an option that will allow the app to automatically add rounded edges to your buttons.

In the meantime, however, if you want a rounded button, simply print the ugly not-round monster, and sand the edges lightly with a high-grit sandpaper. Remember when you do this that a little goes a long way! Be careful not to over-sand!

[04/12/2016]

  • Grouped Customizer controls by purpose

[04/11/2016]

  • Original upload

comments.text:
very cool! 2 suggestions for your code (based off when I made something like this http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1474604):

title: E3D v6 Bowden extruder for Wanhao Duplicator i3

description.text:
E3D v6 Bowden extruder for Wanhao i3

This include holders of step motor to top frame, x-carrage block for E3D and more.

Need to buy

  • E3D v6 (j-head) hotend for 1.75mm (include cooling fan, hotend fitting)
  • PTFE tube for 1.75mm (1 meter) with cold end fitting (I use 0.5m only)
  • Kit of nozzle for E3D v6 (line is very wide, from 0.2 to 1.0mm)
  • Fasteners (M3 and M4 nuts, screws of different lengths)

Mounting of the stepper motor

It is possible to mount of stepper motor on the top of printer's frame only. May be I design a mount for another places.

Holder v1.0 include

  • Step_motor_holder_frame_v.1.0_nut.stl - 2pcs
  • Step_motor_holder_frame_v.1.0_rest.stl - 1pcs
  • Step_motor_clamp_v1.0.stl - 1pcs
  • M4 nuts - 2pcs
  • Short M4 screws (9-10mm) - 2pcs

Holder v1.1 include (more difficult to print than v.1.0)

  • Step_motor_holder_frame_v.1.1.stl -1pcs
  • M4 nuts - 2pcs
  • Short M4 screws (9-10mm) - 2pcs

Cold end

I use:

  • Stock parts of MK10
  • kharar's MK9 bowden extruder - MK9_bowden.stl
  • M3 screws 20mm - 2pcs

Extruder E3D v6 mount

X-axis belt holder is mount on bearing block:

  • E3D_hotend_base_v1.0.stl (need add support in nut's holes) or E3D_hotend_base_v1.0_wSupp.stl - 1pcs (infill 50-60%)
  • E3D_hotend_clamp_v1.0.stl - 1pcs (infill 50-60%)
  • X-axis_endstop_holder.stl - 1pcs
  • M4 nuts - 2pcs
  • M4 screws (40mm or more) - 2pcs
  • M3 screws (7-8mm) for x-endstop holder - 2pcs
  • Stock M3 screws for mount cable chain - 2pcs
  • Stock M2 screws for mount x-endstop - 2pcs

X-axis belt holder is mount on screws in back side:

  • E3D_hotend_base_v1.0.stl (need add support in nut's holes) or E3D_hotend_base_v1.0_wSupp.stl - 1pcs (infill 50-60%)
  • E3D_hotend_clamp_v1.0.stl - 1pcs (infill 50-60%)
  • X-axis_endstop_holder.stl - 1pcs
  • M4 nuts - 4pcs
  • M4 screws (40mm, not more) - 2pcs
  • M4 screws (20-25mm) for back side - 2pcs
  • M3 screws (7-8mm) for x-endstop holder - 2pcs
  • Stock M3 screws for mount cable chain - 2pcs
  • Stock M2 screws for mount x-endstop - 2pcs

What else need to start?

You need desicion few questions:

  • If you install this extruder, than change height of nozzle. It will be higher than stock extruder. You need move the Z-axis endstop below. Not more Z-axis adapter can move down. I desing this simple adapter, you can use it. Print this before installing extruder!
  • It is not critical. In this extruder nozzle misses on the bed. You can make Y-axis endstop adapter and fix it.

Modifications

You may have noticed a lot of holes in mount extruder. This is done for easy mount additions and need M3 screws (7-10mm).
You can make Wire_clamp.stl for fixing wires.

Cooling

I make the adapter (Fan_holder_for_saldots_design_v1.0.stl) for saldot's desing fan holder. One adapter include:

  • Fan_holder_for_saldots_design_v1.0.stl - 1pcs
  • M3 nut - 1pcs
  • M3 screw (20mm) - 1pcs
  • M3 screws (7-10mm) - 2pcs

And I design mount for radial fan 50mm, it is very efficient. But printing is not simple: you should be able to make bridges.

  • Radial_fan_50mm_mount_v1.0.stl - 1pcs
  • M3 nut - 1pcs
  • M3 screws (20mm) - 2pcs
  • M3 screws (7-10mm) - 2pcs
  • Radial fan 5015 (size 50x50x15mm) - 1pcs

Problems

Maximum printing height is main problem in this realise. Height 160mm is limit for non-problem printing. If extruder lifted higher than 160mm, then PTFE tube rubbing the stepper motor.
In the feature I desing new mount for stepper motor. This will increase the height of the print.

Give back "I Made One", please. This is pleasant for designers))

author: JonBAL

print_settings.Notes:: I have yet to print the second floor and roof, however, the second floor should print fine, but do include supports as they will hold up the design so that it will be able to rest on top of the first floor.  The roof shouldn't need supports either, but I have yet to confirm this.

description.text: This is a miniature Brownstone house design at the scale of 1ft = 5mm. The house is in 5 separate pieces: The first floor, second floor, roof, stoop, and back stairs. This is to allow the building to come completely apart for viewing the interior architecture and space. This also allows the building to be modular and take on more floors if needed.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I have yet to print the second floor and roof, however, the second floor should print fine, but do include supports as they will hold up the design so that it will be able to rest on top of the first floor. The roof shouldn't need supports either, but I have yet to confirm this.

title: Mill Centre Finder - Dan Gelbart Inspired

description.text:
Dan Gelbart ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=otSjut1iGGk ) shows how to use this tool at 2 minutes in on his awesome Prototyping YouTube series.

"Virtually Vitamin Free" cost all up less than $1 !!!

Requires a 2032 button cell, a laser pointer and this 3D printed part.

you can get 10 of these laser pointers for $1.90 US on aliexpress.
http://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-shipping-10P-5V-650nm-5mW-Laser-Red-Dot-Module-red-laser-sight-red-laser-diode/32354307065.html

there are 2 locations for the 2032, one is an interference fit to the laser leads, the other is a storage place for the battery (laser off) when not in use.

The laser pointer is focussed by rotating the brass sleeve to get the finest point where appropriate for your centre finding experience!
modelled in OpenSCAD parametric to suit my Bridgeport Mill (68mm diameter quill)

title: Y stabilizer for Printrbot Plus v1

description.text: This is an in-progress remix of Crispy001's "Printrbot Bed Stabilizer", altered to (hopefully) fit on a Printrbot Plus v1 (aka Printrbot Plus 1303 and Printrbot LC 1302).

Crispy001's part was imported into Onshape, overlaid with the official DXF sketch of the Printrbot Plus v1's base, and altered to match.

It has not yet been printed, so I am not positive whether or not it will fit and function.

The onshape document can be found here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d071a82584c20f31c625157d/w/16a6254f67219c3be98870cc/e/9e2a2b6c82ee25cf1d889c58

description.text:
This phone mount will allow you to attach your Lumia 640 phone to any smooth surface.
Attach it to the window of a cruise ship or train and you can not only capture the GPS track of your travels; but you can also let it snap a time lapse photo series as well.

Attach it over the useless screen on your car to give you maps and your favorite music selection at your fingertips.

Best if printed in a firm but slightly flexible material like Soft PLA.

Best if printed in a firm but slightly flexible material like Soft PLA.

The Soft PLA sticks so well I have never needed to use a brim. Just make sure you remove it from the bed before the bed cools off too much.

You will need four small suction cups to attach to the corners.
I picked up Artminds™ Mini Suction Cup Hooks from "Michaels" craft store.

Remove the metal clips they come with and work them into the mount.

The cup needs to be just large enough to stick out from the edge of the mount so you can grab the release nipple.

description.text: Final model of Springs Challenge badge

Revised design 0006 will no longer put pressure on the X stage. End stop triggers are important! They should be fastened securely, no jam the optos, and allow for precise positioning at every new built. These stops are designed so that the Z stage can travel below the build platform, calibrating the Makerbot for a repeatable distance between extruder and platform. This is done by setting X to center and Y all the way to the left. The extruder now misses the build platform, finding its calibration. A calibrated Z stage will bring perfect results at every build without manually positioning. Software will follow. This is a complete set of six end stops. All six end stops are designed to fit right into their respective places. They are wedged for easy fitting into the existing slots on your MakerBot. All end stops should be a tight fit. They are designed for minimum interference with the system and should not jam the optocouplers once the are bent right.

Just push the end stops into the right slots and shorten them as you wish to get maximum travel. There are six different end stops. 
The double "plus" ones go on the x stage. The shorter tab (15mm) goes on the top facing the back wall. The longer one (17mm) goes in the bottom facing the front.
The ones with the small gap go on the Y stage, the longer 50mm tab points to the left, the shorter 43mm tab points to the right.
The ones with the 5mm gap go on the Z stage, the short one in the rear slot pointing up, the long one in the front slot pointing down.
All tabs can be shortnend to get the maximum build space.

title: InMoov Eyeball for Ubisoft Motion Tracking Camera

description.text:
The Hercules-made Ubisoft Motion Tracking Camera is one of the smallest, most versatile, least expensive USB cameras out there and it is already designed to do what you want a camera to do in your InMoov platform. It has an 85 degree field of vision. After trying several different camera configurations including the fish-eye and wide-angle lens options with a Hercules Twist HD camera (both shown in the picture), a couple of other camera and several different eye mechanisms, I decided to go with the current InMoov eye mechanism but to build an eyeball that let's me put the camera in the very front of the eye. You can see from the pictures and from the image showing what those lenses produce in video that by using a smaller lens and pushing it to the front of the eye, the portion of the image that is blocked by the eye-glass face piece is practically eliminated. This camera is only 640x480, but the image quality is very good and the clarity is better than several of the HD cameras I own. You can find this tiny camera, which you can see in one of the images, on eBay, often for less than $10 including shipping. Note that there are two versions of this camera (WD04 and WD19) and this one, WD19, has a microphone. Just tuck it away.

The eyeball-top just glues onto the eyeball-bottom with super glue for PLA (I use Loctite brand) or acetone for ABS. Print the top in any color you want. I suggest you set the filament flow to be a little heavier for the top. I also included a one-piece eyeball that you can print as-is, paint, or slice any way you want for a smaller or larger iris.

The camera fits inside the pupil perfectly and pushes through slightly. There is no mount for the camera. Instead, wrap your camera in blue painters tape, push it into place and "glue" it in with silicone seal. It dries in about 30 minutes, will hold firm and can easily be cut free if you decide to do something else with the camera later. (be sure to avoid getting silicone seal in the connector for the wire.)

I am still tinkering with this design a bit and will post revisions if I make any worthy improvements.

Thanks to Monnerby and Bob Houston as I started with their eyeball thinking I would shrink that whole mechanism down a bit, but ended up just using the very bottom of their eyeball and creating a new, much thinner eye to accommodate the camera. I initially wanted to create a smaller, human sized (25mm) eye that protruded through the eye-glass opening slightly, but realized that doing this would look pretty strange unless I changed the eye-glass piece, plus it might not fit in the same space as the current InMoov mechanism. Better to keep it simple. That will be rev 9 or 10 or somebody else's achievement.

I hope you like this. Please post an image if you use it.

Printer:

Home built Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.3 with a .4 nozzle.

Infill:

5-15%

Notes:

The little eye-top piece is a little troublesome to make because it is so small. Try setting the filament flow a little higher than usual.

title: Right angle adapter for Intex air mattress pump

description.text:
A right angle adapter for your Intex air mattress hand pump.

But why would you want such a thing?

Here's the situation. It's taken far longer than your mother can cope with, but you've finally matured somewhat beyond the nadir of your gross bachelor lifestyle. You've elevated yourself to such a lofty station in life that you now enjoy some of the finer things, like having new furniture. Never mind that the coffee table you keep your full trash bags on came from Ikea, it's still better than that sheet of plywood on top of the cheap filing cabinets that the previous tenant bought at Building 19 (back when Building 19 still existed).

But despite all this personal growth, you still use an air mattress and it's running a little bit flat. The pump port is wedged flush against the headboard (you have furniture now, remember?) and can't quite be reached by the hose at the end of your ACME plunger detonator-style hand pump. To make matters worse, tonight you're being visited by a lovely young caller who thinks they can "change" you.

Now, you could pull up the mattress, rip off the bedding, re-inflate the mattress, and put it all back together... but by that point you might as well wash your sheets and you're already busy snow shoveling out the dining nook. Surely there's a way to re-inflate your mattress before your hot date that only involves a level of effort consistent with your irregular use of the shower...

Well now there is!

Just print out one of these handy right angle adapters, wedge it down in there and get pumping! The night is saved; you have a firm "sleeping" surface, you still get to look like a "challenge" to your guest, and you'll even have time left over to scrape those wet newspapers out of the kitchen sink!†

How to use:

  • Print it.
  • Unscrew the inflation port thingy on your mattress and shove the adapter's fight pipe in there.
  • Plug your pump into the other end.
  • Get pumping.

  • Evaluate what your next step to "get it together" looks like.

    † (Which is really weird, because you don't actually have a newspaper subscription...)

Mine is printed in ABS, but I bet you PLA hippies will have no trouble.

I created the corner braces for taller MP-CNC builds I was having trouble with the shake when it jerked hopefully this will make it a little more rigid. there are two different designs.

Just a update I printed the corner peaces out in PETG witch is one of my favorite filaments due to the higher melting temps low warp and good strength and flexibility, i did notice when i installed it that i cracked a couple braces from over tightening I will be beefing up the braces a little more to insure no cracking next go round.

In addition I will be modifying the brace so that you will not have to take apart the MP-CNC at all to add it.

on the latest version I thickened up a few areas, hopefully it helps a little

title: Fleks 3D plate holder for Flux 3D Delta

description.text:
This thing is a holding plate for the Fleks 3D 8 Inch Delta build plate that makes it a perfect fit for the Flux 3D Delta. You need two to hold the plate firmly in place without using any magnets or clips.

This requires precision printing with limited tolerances (otherwise the build plate will move). Make sure that there are no warps or imperfections and clean up any overhang.

Do NOT attempt to use 3 plates and leave the corner with the flux button empty to make filament loading stay simple.
